s.text: The CEO of Office Depot told Reuters that he's using bodyguards because of threats, apparently from his employees.
But the merger of two former competitors is inherently more suspicious than a company that comes to dominate the market through its own growth.
But the merger of two former competitors is inherently more suspicious than a company that comes to dominate the market through its own growth.
If the fast-food world had only three players, and McDonalds's proposed to buy out Burger King, how reassured would we be if they offered the palliative of selling a few franchises to Taco Bell?

But the agency has also become more sensitive to the details of particular products and markets.
In other words, forget market-share equations: Look at prices to find the real story.

By this measure, the companies' analysts figure, the combination of Staples' 553 superstores in 100 markets across the United States and Canada and Office Depot's 571 North American outlets (mostly superstores) would still command less than 10 percent of the market.

By this measure, the companies' analysts figure, the combination of Staples' 553 superstores in 100 markets across the United States and Canada and Office Depot's 571 North American outlets (mostly superstores) would still command less than 10 percent of the market.

The commission seems to be giving some credence to the claimed benefits of the merger, while hedging its bets on the competition issue by shoring up Office Max and seeding healthy retail conflict in scores of communities.
